parameters.source_text:
CASE 82:
PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY TOWARD
AN ABUSIVE PATIENT
Ben is a 48-year-old man with terminal metastatic melanoma. Originally diagnosed 3 years
ago, the cancer has spread despite all treatments, including surgical resection, chemotherapy
and radiotherapy. He is angry at having terminal cancer and has been verbally abusive to
numerous staff members, face to face, on the telephone and via email, and including senior
consultants, junior doctors, specialist cancer nurses and ward nurses. Ben has made sev-
eral formal complaints against the hospital, in addition to his local District Nursing service
and community palliative care team. He has, however, maintained strong and friendly
relationships with a few oncology team members and his own GP. Ben has had his care trans-
ferred from another hospital and between oncologists at his current hospital due to recurrent
breakdowns in relationships with his doctors and nurses due to his behaviour.
Ben attends the emergency department at 2 a.m. with uncontrolled pain. The emergency
department doctors have referred him to oncology as he is a cancer patient and have refused
to see him. You are the junior oncology doctor working overnight in the hospital. After
politely introducing yourself and appropriately commenting on the difficulties you are aware
he is facing from his disease, Ben tells you aggressively to stop being condescending, swears
at you and makes a derogatory comment about your physical appearance. He demands to see
a senior oncology team member who he says knows his case and he has a good relationship
with. You are the only oncology doctor available to see the patient for the next 7 hours when
the shift changes.
Questions
• Does a doctor’s duty extend to treating patients who are aggressive and verbally
abusive?
• Does it make a difference if the behaviour is as a result of the patient reacting
badly to their condition or illness?
• What if there is no one else able to take over care?

data.vignette: A 48-year-old man with terminal metastatic melanoma comes to the emergency department at 2 a.m. with severe, escalating cancer pain. His disease has progressed despite multiple treatments. He has a long history of verbally abusing clinicians and filing complaints, and his outpatient care has been repeatedly transferred after conflict. You are the junior oncology doctor covering overnight. When you introduce yourself, he swears at you, makes a derogatory comment about your appearance, and demands a senior oncologist he trusts. No senior oncology clinician is available for several hours, and the ED team is asking oncology to direct analgesia because he is on a palliative plan. Hospital policy permits clinicians to set limits and request security support, but it also expects timely symptom relief for patients in distress. You must decide how to proceed for the rest of the night.
data.choice_1: Enter the room and manage his pain now with a staff chaperone
data.choice_2: Decline in-person care and defer oncology assessment until the morning team arrives

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief sentence clarifying the jurisdiction/policy basis that makes *both* approaches legally permissible. For example: “Per hospital policy and local law, clinicians may delay non-emergent bedside evaluation when there is a credible safety concern, provided the patient is not abandoned and symptoms are addressed through alternative coverage.” Also clarify that the ED team can legally administer opioids under standing protocols or on-call orders even if oncology does not come to bedside immediately.

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
Revise Choice 2 so it is not simple abandonment/withholding analgesia. Make both options clinically defensible by ensuring pain relief still occurs while acknowledging staff safety and boundary-setting. For example:
- Choice 1: “Go to bedside now with security/chaperone and personally assess and titrate opioids/adjuncts.”
- Choice 2: “Do not enter the room overnight due to safety concerns; instead, give time-limited analgesia orders remotely (e.g., ED palliative pain protocol, opioid titration parameters, adjuvants) and require a behavioral agreement/security presence before any bedside oncology assessment in the morning.”
Also add a concrete safety detail that makes deferring bedside contact reasonable (e.g., prior threats, throwing objects, history of assault, current intoxication/agitation), and explicitly state what minimum symptom-management will still be provided if you do not enter.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the competing values explicit in the facts (without naming them): (1) immediate relief of severe suffering vs (2) credible risk to clinician safety/psychological harm and a duty to maintain professional boundaries. Add concrete details that make safety concerns serious (e.g., patient has thrown objects/attempted to hit staff tonight, refuses to stop abusive behavior after warning, security feels escalation risk). Also clarify that deferring care is not simply neglect by specifying what care is still provided if you do not enter (e.g., analgesia orders via ED protocol, security present, alternative clinician/telehealth).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten each option so small wording changes do not flip the ethical meaning. Define what “manage his pain now” entails (e.g., opioid escalation, palliative sedation discussion, monitoring) and what “defer oncology assessment” still includes (e.g., continue current meds only vs authorize ED to titrate opioids per standing order). Explicitly state whether the patient will accept treatment from you; if he refuses, say so, because that shifts the dilemma from abandonment to respecting refusal.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what the junior doctor can safely do and what the consequences are. Specify: (a) whether ED can legally/procedurally provide adequate analgesia without oncology bedside evaluation, (b) whether security/chaperone meaningfully reduces risk, and (c) what the likely patient experience is overnight under each option (e.g., continued uncontrolled pain vs partial relief). This will help graders converge on the same value tradeoff rather than debating clinical logistics.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither looks like obvious abandonment. Revise Choice 2 to be a clinically and ethically defensible alternative, such as: “Do not enter the room; set firm behavioral limits through the door/phone, request security, and authorize the ED to follow a rapid opioid titration/comfort-care order set until the morning oncologist can reassess.” Alternatively, make Choice 1 ethically costly by increasing credible personal risk (e.g., patient is escalating, has a history of assault, security warns risk remains even with chaperone). Ensure both choices have real costs: immediate relief vs staff safety/system integrity, or immediate boundary-setting vs ongoing suffering/erosion of trust.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace loaded descriptors that bias toward limiting care. For example, change “long history of verbally abusing clinicians” to “recurrent episodes of verbally abusive language toward staff documented in the chart,” and change “swears at you, makes a derogatory comment about your appearance” to “uses profanity and personal insults toward you.” Remove “demands a senior oncologist he trusts” or rephrase to “requests a specific attending clinician.” Avoid implying the patient is ‘difficult’ beyond what is needed to establish a safety/limits dilemma.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the clinical facts and who is responsible for analgesia. Specify whether the ED has already provided opioids, whether the patient has an existing opioid regimen (e.g., high-dose long-acting opioid with breakthrough dosing), and what is being asked of oncology (dose escalation vs PCA vs admission). Remove redundant conflict-history phrasing (“repeatedly transferred after conflict”) unless needed. Clarify the immediate decision window (e.g., ‘for the next 4–6 hours’).

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Rephrase profanity/insult content in more clinical terms and avoid explicit slurs. For example: “He uses aggressive, profane language and directs personal insults at you.” Consider adding that security is available per policy without detailing threatening language. Ensure no explicit discriminatory slur is quoted.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices parallel, specific, and 10–15 words without extra qualifiers. Example:
- Choice 1: “Provide bedside analgesia now with a chaperone and set behavioral limits.”
- Choice 2: “Provide analgesia via ED protocol and delay oncology bedside review until morning.”
This keeps the decision binary while avoiding ‘decline care’ ambiguity.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 reads like avoidable abandonment because the patient is in severe, escalating pain and policy expects timely symptom relief; Choice 1 looks clearly preferable. To rebalance: (1) Make the safety risk more concrete and imminent (e.g., prior physical aggression toward staff, throwing objects tonight, refusing to keep hands visible, security warns the room is unsafe). (2) Add that the junior doctor feels unprepared to safely manage complex opioid/titration/palliative sedation without senior backup, and an error could cause oversedation/respiratory depression or violate an existing palliative plan. (3) Clarify that the patient is demanding a specific senior clinician and is refusing assessment/consent with anyone else, raising questions about whether entering now will help or escalate. (4) Ensure both options carry comparable moral cost: Choice 1 risks staff safety/setting precedent for tolerated abuse; Choice 2 risks uncontrolled suffering and perceived abandonment.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because there are obvious middle paths: provide analgesia via ED/acute pain service, give phone orders without entering, involve security immediately with firm boundary-setting, swap to another available clinician (ED attending/hospitalist/palliative consult), or offer brief in-person assessment at the doorway. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives, e.g.: (1) ED policy requires oncology to evaluate in person before any opioid escalation beyond home regimen; acute pain/palliative teams are not available overnight; (2) remote orders are prohibited for this patient due to prior adverse event/controlled substances policy; (3) security can stand by but cannot remain in the room or restrain unless physical assault occurs; (4) no other clinician with prescribing authority for the palliative plan is available until morning. Then the only feasible choices are to enter now (with chaperone) vs not enter until morning.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Currently, widely accepted professional/legal expectations (ED duty to evaluate/treat emergent suffering; non-abandonment; institutional policies on timely symptom relief) make Choice 2 potentially clearly noncompliant unless additional context creates a genuine gray zone. Add details showing why guidelines/policy do not settle it, e.g.: (1) Documented behavioral contract allowing clinicians to postpone non-emergent in-person encounters when staff safety is threatened, with ED permitted to provide interim analgesia; (2) confirm he is hemodynamically stable and has already received standard rescue doses, with no signs of acute complication, so the question is escalation/complex management rather than basic emergency treatment; (3) state that entering could violate a hospital harassment/safety policy that obligates staff to disengage when abuse escalates. This creates a true conflict between competing institutional duties rather than a straightforward standards-of-care violation.

feedback.clinical:
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief sentence clarifying the jurisdiction/policy basis that makes *both* approaches legally permissible. For example: “Per hospital policy and local law, clinicians may delay non-emergent bedside evaluation when there is a credible safety concern, provided the patient is not abandoned and symptoms are addressed through alternative coverage.” Also clarify that the ED team can legally administer opioids under standing protocols or on-call orders even if oncology does not come to bedside immediately.
non_triviality: Revise Choice 2 so it is not simple abandonment/withholding analgesia. Make both options clinically defensible by ensuring pain relief still occurs while acknowledging staff safety and boundary-setting. For example:
- Choice 1: “Go to bedside now with security/chaperone and personally assess and titrate opioids/adjuncts.”
- Choice 2: “Do not enter the room overnight due to safety concerns; instead, give time-limited analgesia orders remotely (e.g., ED palliative pain protocol, opioid titration parameters, adjuvants) and require a behavioral agreement/security presence before any bedside oncology assessment in the morning.”
Also add a concrete safety detail that makes deferring bedside contact reasonable (e.g., prior threats, throwing objects, history of assault, current intoxication/agitation), and explicitly state what minimum symptom-management will still be provided if you do not enter.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the competing values explicit in the facts (without naming them): (1) immediate relief of severe suffering vs (2) credible risk to clinician safety/psychological harm and a duty to maintain professional boundaries. Add concrete details that make safety concerns serious (e.g., patient has thrown objects/attempted to hit staff tonight, refuses to stop abusive behavior after warning, security feels escalation risk). Also clarify that deferring care is not simply neglect by specifying what care is still provided if you do not enter (e.g., analgesia orders via ED protocol, security present, alternative clinician/telehealth).
directional_stability: Tighten each option so small wording changes do not flip the ethical meaning. Define what “manage his pain now” entails (e.g., opioid escalation, palliative sedation discussion, monitoring) and what “defer oncology assessment” still includes (e.g., continue current meds only vs authorize ED to titrate opioids per standing order). Explicitly state whether the patient will accept treatment from you; if he refuses, say so, because that shifts the dilemma from abandonment to respecting refusal.
interpretive_consensus: Reduce ambiguity about what the junior doctor can safely do and what the consequences are. Specify: (a) whether ED can legally/procedurally provide adequate analgesia without oncology bedside evaluation, (b) whether security/chaperone meaningfully reduces risk, and (c) what the likely patient experience is overnight under each option (e.g., continued uncontrolled pain vs partial relief). This will help graders converge on the same value tradeoff rather than debating clinical logistics.
decision_equipoise: Rebalance the options so neither looks like obvious abandonment. Revise Choice 2 to be a clinically and ethically defensible alternative, such as: “Do not enter the room; set firm behavioral limits through the door/phone, request security, and authorize the ED to follow a rapid opioid titration/comfort-care order set until the morning oncologist can reassess.” Alternatively, make Choice 1 ethically costly by increasing credible personal risk (e.g., patient is escalating, has a history of assault, security warns risk remains even with chaperone). Ensure both choices have real costs: immediate relief vs staff safety/system integrity, or immediate boundary-setting vs ongoing suffering/erosion of trust.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace loaded descriptors that bias toward limiting care. For example, change “long history of verbally abusing clinicians” to “recurrent episodes of verbally abusive language toward staff documented in the chart,” and change “swears at you, makes a derogatory comment about your appearance” to “uses profanity and personal insults toward you.” Remove “demands a senior oncologist he trusts” or rephrase to “requests a specific attending clinician.” Avoid implying the patient is ‘difficult’ beyond what is needed to establish a safety/limits dilemma.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify the clinical facts and who is responsible for analgesia. Specify whether the ED has already provided opioids, whether the patient has an existing opioid regimen (e.g., high-dose long-acting opioid with breakthrough dosing), and what is being asked of oncology (dose escalation vs PCA vs admission). Remove redundant conflict-history phrasing (“repeatedly transferred after conflict”) unless needed. Clarify the immediate decision window (e.g., ‘for the next 4–6 hours’).
safety_compliance: Rephrase profanity/insult content in more clinical terms and avoid explicit slurs. For example: “He uses aggressive, profane language and directs personal insults at you.” Consider adding that security is available per policy without detailing threatening language. Ensure no explicit discriminatory slur is quoted.

- Choice 1: “Provide bedside analgesia now with a chaperone and set behavioral limits.”
- Choice 2: “Provide analgesia via ED protocol and delay oncology bedside review until morning.”
This keeps the decision binary while avoiding ‘decline care’ ambiguity.

balanced_difficulty: As written, Choice 2 reads like avoidable abandonment because the patient is in severe, escalating pain and policy expects timely symptom relief; Choice 1 looks clearly preferable. To rebalance: (1) Make the safety risk more concrete and imminent (e.g., prior physical aggression toward staff, throwing objects tonight, refusing to keep hands visible, security warns the room is unsafe). (2) Add that the junior doctor feels unprepared to safely manage complex opioid/titration/palliative sedation without senior backup, and an error could cause oversedation/respiratory depression or violate an existing palliative plan. (3) Clarify that the patient is demanding a specific senior clinician and is refusing assessment/consent with anyone else, raising questions about whether entering now will help or escalate. (4) Ensure both options carry comparable moral cost: Choice 1 risks staff safety/setting precedent for tolerated abuse; Choice 2 risks uncontrolled suffering and perceived abandonment.

Then the only feasible choices are to enter now (with chaperone) vs not enter until morning.
no_guideline_override: Currently, widely accepted professional/legal expectations (ED duty to evaluate/treat emergent suffering; non-abandonment; institutional policies on timely symptom relief) make Choice 2 potentially clearly noncompliant unless additional context creates a genuine gray zone. Add details showing why guidelines/policy do not settle it, e.g.: (1) Documented behavioral contract allowing clinicians to postpone non-emergent in-person encounters when staff safety is threatened, with ED permitted to provide interim analgesia; (2) confirm he is hemodynamically stable and has already received standard rescue doses, with no signs of acute complication, so the question is escalation/complex management rather than basic emergency treatment; (3) state that entering could violate a hospital harassment/safety policy that obligates staff to disengage when abuse escalates. This creates a true conflict between competing institutional duties rather than a straightforward standards-of-care violation.

data.vignette: A 48-year-old man with terminal metastatic melanoma arrives to the ED at 2 a.m. with severe cancer pain despite high-dose home opioids. He is hemodynamically stable and has no new neurologic deficits or signs of acute bleeding. The ED has given repeated rescue doses and adjuvants, but he is still in distress and is asking for stronger medication and “to be knocked out.” The chart documents prior incidents of aggressive, profane language and one episode of hitting a staff member. Tonight he has shoved a bedside table and refuses to answer questions unless a specific attending oncologist comes. That attending will not arrive for several hours. Overnight, oncology must see him in person to start a PCA or consider palliative sedation, and remote opioid escalation is restricted after a prior oversedation event. Security can stand nearby but cannot restrain him unless he becomes violent. Hospital policy and local law allow delaying bedside evaluation when there is a credible safety concern if interim symptom treatment is arranged. You must decide what to do overnight.
data.choice_1: Enter now with a chaperone to assess and escalate analgesia at bedside
data.choice_2: Stay out overnight and authorize ED protocol analgesia until the attending arrives

data.vignette: A 48-year-old man with terminal metastatic melanoma arrives to the ED at 2 a.m. with severe cancer pain despite high-dose home opioids. He is hemodynamically stable and has no new neurologic deficits or signs of acute bleeding. The ED has given repeated rescue doses and adjuvants, but he is still in distress and is asking for stronger medication and “to be knocked out.” The chart documents prior incidents of aggressive, profane language and one episode of hitting a staff member. Tonight he has shoved a bedside table and refuses to answer questions unless a specific attending oncologist comes. That attending will not arrive for several hours. Overnight, oncology must see him in person to start a PCA or consider palliative sedation, and remote opioid escalation is restricted after a prior oversedation event. Security can stand nearby but cannot restrain him unless he becomes violent. Hospital policy and local law allow delaying bedside evaluation when there is a credible safety concern if interim symptom treatment is arranged. You must decide what to do overnight.

choice_1.choice: Enter now with a chaperone to assess and escalate analgesia at bedside

choice_2.choice: Stay out overnight and authorize ED protocol analgesia until the attending arrives

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient has decisional capacity and is explicitly requesting immediate bedside evaluation/escalation now (and/or explicitly refuses waiting for the attending), so the delay clearly overrides his stated preference.

Add a clause that ED protocol analgesia is already at its maximum/ineffective and cannot safely be escalated without oncology bedside evaluation (e.g., PCA or palliative sedation), so delaying until morning predictably leaves him in severe uncontrolled pain.

Add a clause specifying the concrete harms/risks on both sides (e.g., that he remains in 10/10 pain despite ED protocol analgesia, and that he has made a direct threat or is actively swinging/throwing objects such that entering now creates a credible risk of staff injury).

Add a clause explicitly linking the decision to fairness/resource protection (e.g., 'only one overnight oncology clinician covers the entire hospital/ED, and entering would require diverting security/staff from other patients') so the justice tradeoff is unambiguous.

data.vignette: A 48-year-old man with terminal metastatic melanoma arrives to the ED at 2 a.m. with 10/10 cancer pain despite high-dose home opioids. He is hemodynamically stable. He has decisional capacity and is explicitly requesting immediate escalation of analgesia and palliative sedation. The ED has given repeated rescue doses and adjuvants under protocol. He remains in severe distress. ED protocol dosing is at its maximum, and further escalation is restricted after a prior oversedation event. Overnight, oncology must evaluate him in person to start a PCA or consider palliative sedation. The chart documents prior aggressive, profane behavior and one episode of hitting a staff member. Tonight he has shoved a bedside table and has warned he may strike anyone who approaches. Security can stand nearby but cannot restrain him unless he becomes violent. Only one overnight oncology clinician covers the hospital, and pulling security to his room may divert care from other patients. Policy allows delaying bedside evaluation for credible safety concerns if interim symptom treatment is arranged. You must decide what to do overnight.

choice_1.choice: Enter now with a chaperone to assess and escalate analgesia at bedside

choice_2.choice: Stay out overnight and authorize ED protocol analgesia until the attending arrives
